newsitem.title: INDIA: Indian call eases on reports of cash reserve cut.
newsitem.headline: Indian call eases on reports of cash reserve cut.

text.p: Indian call money ended Friday in the 9.50-9.75 percent range, down from the day's opening levels of 10.0-10.75 percent, dealers said. Gilt yields were stable in moderate trade, they said.
Call money eased on news reports that the Reserve Bank of India was willing to consider a cut in cash reserve requirements for banks, dealers said.
"Sentiment improved on reports of an expected cut in cash reserve requirements," a dealer at a foreign bank said. "Borrowers were quoting lower rates from the morning itself."
Dealers said gilt yields were stable in limited trade.
"There was not much trade today as market participants are waiting to see if the reports of a cut in cash reserves takes place," a dealer said.
No trades were reported in certificates of deposit or commercial paper. The rates on inter-corporate deposits remained steady at 17.0-19.0 percent for top-rated borrowers.
